job_title: Student Caller in San Antonio, TX
pros: The admissions office has a calm working environment; being a student caller is mainly independent work, which gives you a great opportunity to build leaderships skills, as well as communication skills.
cons: Because it's a work study position, you can't really be promoted.

job_title: Admin in San Antonio, TX
pros: Okay place to work for you education professionals.
cons: Facilities were a bit dated.

job_title: Director Level Position in San Antonio, TX
pros: Students a joy to work with and overall atmosphere friendly, non-pretentious, and cooperative.
cons: The canaries in the coal mine have long since not returned. If you seek to work here, they are worth listening to. The so-called "right sizing" of employee numbers began well BEFORE the pandemic. Over 50 staff have left in past 12 months. Given that it is a small school, this tells you everything you need to know about the overall climate and the level of confidence in the place. Those jobs didn't go away. They just got absorbed by staff still there. Administration won't be held accountable for their incompetence or their outright sabotage of new and creative ideas; in fact, they get protected. This place is living in the past with no clear sense of its identity and future. Why? "Because," you'll hear, "this is who we are." No matter that the times have changed. Staff salaries have remained static as well. No raises in last few years. There are even employees with master's degrees making $13/hour, below living wage. Nevertheless, Pres. Melby continued to receive a $20,000+ salary increase each year of her tenure (you can easily find school's tax records online to show this). In other words, values and practices do not line up. It's an unhealthy place to work. Work here and after some years you, too, will feel the ill effects mentally, emotionally, and physically. I say all this after having loved so much of my job. Just not a healthy place.Feels like a sinking ship. New president, new mission statement won't change that. Etc. Etc.

job_title: Data Analyst in San Antonio, TX
pros: OLLU has a strong sense of community full of supportive staff members. The campus is small but has a lot to offer from a cafeteria, a starbucks, a gym (shared with students), a beautiful campus, and daily mass. While it might be in the middle of a neighborhood riddled with it's own troubles, OLLU always felt safe and well-monitored by the campus police. Everyone at OLLU makes you feel welcome.
cons: OLLU has been around for a very long time, so there are challenges that come along with old buildings. However, OLLU is working hard to make updates whenever possible.

job_title: A Technology Staffer in San Antonio, TX
pros: The best reasons to work at OLLU are the family atmosphere and general friendliness of the place. Most employees get along very well with one another and people who don't fit in tend not to stay around. Most employees are competent and hard working, and everyone has the best interests of the students in mind. Many of us "go the extra mile" to solve problems, especially when we know that the person has already had trouble in solving a particular problem.
cons: The only downside is that some of the offices and employees don't communicate well with other offices and employees that they are supposed to have close contact with. Case in point: Financial Aid and the Business Office. You'd think it would kill a member of one office to walk 20 feet and talk to someone in the other office. Instead, they just bounce a student back and forth between them, never making it easy to solve problems.

job_title: ITS Help Desk Student Technician III in San Antonio, TX
pros:
-Staff lunches are really good
-You are off by yourself a lot
-You are forced to learn on your feet
-The staff and faculty that you serve around the school are really nice and appreciative 
-You work with student employees
cons:
-No training
-Given vague instructions for tasks or "I don't know, you figure it out"
-Office politics hinder work production on a daily basis
-"Every man for themselves" attitude, even on co-op projects or critical tasks that need to be done
-Alot of "he said, she said" nonsense 
-The staff in my area where so scared to make a mistake due to a power hunger boss and CTO
- They treat their work study students really bad. They give them no guidance, no help, they get punished if they do something wrong, and they overwork them so much that it starts to affect their studies
-Projects take a while to get started due to bickering among the staff
-You feel like you are always watching out for yourself instead of being on a team.

review_title: Good people make up for the salary
